Problem:
Let \\( H(s) = \\frac{1}{s^2 + as + b} \\) be a transfer function of a linear time-invariant system, where \\(a\\) and \\(b\\) are constants. Suppose an input signal \\( x(t) \\) is transformed into the output \\( y(t) \\) through this system. We examine the effect of input transformations using a Laplace transform \\( L(x(t)) = X(s) \\) and its inverse on the resulting output.

If an input \\( x(t) \\) changes to \\( x'(t) = x(t)e^{ct} \\) where \\(c\\) is a constant, and the system processes \\( x'(t) \\) without any intervention, will \\( y(t) \\) be the same as if the original \\( x(t) \\) was processed?
Explanation: The transformation \\( x'(t) = x(t)e^{ct} \\) alters the Laplace transform of the input to \\( X'(s) = X(s-c) \\). The output therefore becomes \\( Y(s) = H(s)X(s-c) \\) instead of \\( H(s)X(s) \\). The modification in the frequency domain due to the shift \\( s-c \\) fundamentally changes the resulting time-domain output.
